repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Heat Supply Restructuring and
            Conservation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated highly
            satisfactory, namely due to the successful institutional
            development objective of the investment component, and
            sustainability is also highly likely. The high motivation,
            and commitment of successive governments, and that of the
            district heating enterprises (DHE), to improve energy
            efficiency, provide competitive services, and protect the
            environment, greatly contributed to this outcome. Among the
            many lessons learned, it is suggested that: 1) to reduce the
            overly bureaucratic, and time consuming procurement process,
            standardized technical specifications required for DHEs
            items be established; increase the international shopping
            limit for these items; and, consider the use of local
            language for procurement documents; 2) priority be given to
            metering of total purchases, and sales of heat, early on
            during implementation to prevent underestimating the level
            of heat transmission losses, and DHEs variable operating
            costs, and provide better cost savings opportunities; 3)
            since depreciation is a major operating cost in the
            capital-intensive district heating, and energy enterprises,
            it may undermine the integrity of financial accounts when
            inflation reaches high levels. Thus, the issue should be
            addressed at the country level, not just in the context of a
            single operation; and, 4) credit lines should be subject to
            acceptable commercial practices, and, when in partnership
            with other international financial institutions, a blending
            of funds should be provided.
